page.title: 13THE GRAVEL PITS, HILTON
page.content: This 75acre site was used for gravel extraction until 1945. The area was bought by the Derbyshire Naturalist Trust in 1972 and developed as a nature reserve. It is now a valued village amenity,used by the local schools for field study work and visited by other members of the Trust. The five pits flooded and gradually the areas around them naturalised, first as reed swamp, scrub then woodland. Trees include willow, birch, scots - pine, oak and the rare black poplar. There are 280 plant species, including three kinds of orchids, - marsh, twayblade and spotted. Birds include warblers, grebes, mallard, coot, Canada geese, woodpeckers, field fare and red wings. 18 butterfly species and 150 different moths have also been identified.
